properties.story_excerpt: ClearWater broke ground in the community of Cofan Dureno in late 2011, and has since built 105 rainwater catchment systems in 6 communities, providing clean water for over 700 people.
properties.story: The ClearWater project broke ground in the community of Cofan Dureno from November, 2011 when 52 rainwater catchment systems were built, providing 350 people with much-needed clean water. From November 2013 through January 2014, ClearWater built 53 rain catchments systems in the communities of Bavoroe, Ukavati, Pisorie Canqque, and Uttuvoe.

properties.story_excerpt: Beginning in the Secoya communities of San Pablo and Bellavista in 2012, ClearWater has installed 76 rainwater systems in Secoya territory, serving approximately 500 people.
properties.story: The Secoya are highly organized and dedicated to building clean water solutions for the nationality. ClearWater first began building in the communities of San Pablo and Bellavista in 2012. Over the months of July and August 2013 ClearWater installed an additional 55 rainwater systems in Secoya territory, in the communities of San Pablo and Siecoya Remolino.

properties.story_excerpt: In 2013, ClearWater began a pilot project in the Waorani community of Yawepare using a new long-lasting metal design to build 13 water systems, benefitting 75+ people. More to come in 2014.
properties.story: In 2013, ClearWater began a pilot project in the Waorani community of Yawepare using a new design for metal catchment system frames that will last five times longer than wooden frames. 13 systems were built, benefitting 75 people. ClearWater will expand construction in additional Waorani communities starting in early 2014.

properties.story_excerpt: Installation of 53 catchment systems has already begun in the Kichwa village of Rumipamba, starting in May of 2013, which will benefit approximately 350 people. ClearWater will also be working with other Kichwa communities in the near future, ensuring clean water for all oil-affected indigenous communities.

ClearWater began installations with the Siona nationality in October 2012, constructing 20 rain catchment systems in the community of Sotosiaya, benefitting over 100 people. From November 2013 through January 2014, an additional 36 rainwater systems were built in the communities of Aboquehuira, Bi'aña, and Orahuëaya. Siona technicians working for ClearWater are dedicated to improving the living conditions for all Siona community members by providing them with clean drinking water.

ClearWater began installations in the Cofán community of Sinangue, located in the foothills of the Andes mountains, in late November of 2013. 24 systems were built, benefitting over 100 people. Systems were completed in January of 2014.
